FacilityName: MFA Agri Service - West Liquid Plant - Centralia

_accidents.CF_Other: Due to attempted theft, valves had not been locked with cable tie

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Risk Management Plan - Executive Summary

Facility: MFA West Liquid Plant
Location: 22501 North March Road, Centralia, Mo.
Contact:  Jim Gesling
Phone:    573-682-2157


1. The Facility Policy

MFA Incorporated and the employees of the MFA West Liquid Plant in Centralia are committed to the prevention of any accidental release of anhydrous ammonia. If an accidental release should occur, the facility is prepared to work with the Boone County Fire Protection District, and other authorities, to mitigate any release and minimize the impact of the release to people and the environment.

2. Facility Information

The primary activity at the facility is the receiving, storage and distribution of liquid and dry bulk fertilizers, and anhydrous ammonia for direct application as crop nutrients.

Product will typically be delivered by tanker trucks that hold 50,000 pounds, but might be delivered by railroad tank car. The facility has two 30,000-gallon storage tanks, seventy-six, 1,000-gallon nurse tanks and two 560-gallon tank applicators for product distribution and application.

3. The Accidental Release Prevention Program.

The facility has implemented the provisions of "Safety Requirements for the Storage and Handling of Anhydrous Ammonia, K-61.1, 1999", published by The American National Standards Institute, Inc., the Missouri Anhydrous Ammonia Law, and the standards of the U.S. Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA), 29 CFR 1910.111, "Storage and handling of Anhydrous Ammonia". The facility will work to maintain the newest codes as time and budgets allow.


4. The Five-year Accident History

There was an accidental release of anhydrous ammonia from a parked nurse tank on August 15, 2010 at approximately 10:09 a.m. There was a release of approximately 4,200 pounds to the air due to the attempted theft of product believed for production of methamphetamine. There were no injuries on or off-site and minor vegetation damage both on-site and off-site. There was no

sheltering in place or evacuations required from the release.

5. The Emergency Response Program.

The facility has;
    a. a written emergency action plan, in accordance with OSHAStandard, 29 CFR 1910.38;

    b. provided State and Local authorities with the emergency planning and community 
          right-to-know information as required under SARA Title III (EPCRA);

    c. a written emergency response program, in accordance with OSHA Standard, 29 CFR 
          1910.120, including pre-emergency planning and employee training.

6. Planned changes to improve safety.

Safety improvement is an on-going process at the facility. Periodic evaluations are performed to assess the maintenance of safe conditions. There are no additional specific anhydrous ammonia safety recommendations for implementation at this time.


    9/30/10
